section.text: Thank you very much. I guess good evening guys if you're in Europe. So Michael, Bernie can you hear me, okay.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matt Ramsay", "section_number": 1, "uuid": "1301d31e-7525-48ee-8203-91d88f5f1801", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen"}

section.text: Yeah, [Foreign Speech].
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bernie Blegen", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "8aa584cf-29c6-4582-af61-de359963546b", "speaker_title": "VP and CFO at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Thanks guys. So two different questions from me. One sort of related to the model and the near term and the other one on a different topic. So the first question, Bernie, if you could help us a little bit, I mean the guidance was a bit light and you talked about some of the macro conditions, but it seemed like weakness was concentrated in the storage and computing segment. So if you could maybe talk about things by segment and what you're guidance implies on a quarterly basis by segment. I think that would be helpful and then I have a follow up. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matt Ramsay", "section_number": 3, "uuid": "9e301920-a720-4f9f-b0b3-e64c852d6ee8", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen"}

section.text: Sure, just to clarify that the softness that we're seeing is both in the storage and computing as well as consumer. The other segments are still positioned to show growth between Q3 and Q4. The only sort of qualifier that we're still trying to learn about the strength and the runrate of the communications of that segment. So I think what we've done is we feel very, very comfortable with both, how we've been communicating our expected results, but we've added a little conservatism to the outlook.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bernie Blegen", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "7dad55b2-f40f-4647-9929-7051c670fff9", "speaker_title": "VP and CFO at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Got it. Great. And thank you that. Michael, my second question is on the topic of China, and over the last, I'd say three or four weeks since some of the new commerce and BIS restrictions have come into place, I've been getting a ton of investor questions about this topic with relation to your company on two fronts. I guess the first being, MPS has a significant employee base in China. If you could maybe quantify what maybe percentage of your employees and in what functions are actually in China, and if you've heard from any of these restrictions that there could be any restrictions on those employees need to relocate anybody, those kind of things? And then the second part of the question is on your manufacturing footprint. I know it's spread across China, Taiwan, increasingly in Korea. We've heard some stories from semi cap companies needing to pull employees out of SMIC for example, in other places because of these new restrictions. So anything in your manufacturing operations that might be disrupted at all because of some of the China restrictions and how far are you guys along or maybe the mix of your capacity that's now outside of China. You get this nature of the questions, but they've been a pretty frequent and acute over the last three or four weeks. So, it would be great if you could just kind of address some of those topics. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matt Ramsay", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "94f327fe-0006-45d0-b271-0bda8aeb9db0", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen"}

section.text: Yes, very nice questions. Michael, I'm glad you asked, that what all your concern is I think most of the people totally misconstrued whatever the regulation is. And we do have a presence, we have a large presence within China. This is a US companies, okay, and we're not subject for sanctions at all. We don't have to have the people to leave -- Americans have to leave an MPS office within China and that's not in the sanction entity list, and we are not in a sanction entity list. And other one is the manufacturing in the last couple of quarters, we already talked about it. We've diversified out of China and we're starting five, six years ago. Also, I should mention that we thought about it on the engineering manpower. This MPS started at 2017, and we are in Barcelona now. We've moved a very large team here with the local government support. We are outside of China, and that's not because we -- because of sanctions, because we want to diversify. Geometrically we'll -- we will grow into a different region, in the same time zones, wherever we want. We give our customers the better support.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Hsing", "section_number": 6, "uuid": "66b85e81-5410-450c-b633-32dee473de3a", "speaker_title": "CEO and Founder at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: And just to finish up on Michael's comment there, to be perfectly clear, our technology and our products are not subject to restrictions.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bernie Blegen", "section_number": 7, "uuid": "80bb732d-56fb-4c7f-adaa-484dac07462d", "speaker_title": "VP and CFO at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: No, thank you very much. Just a really, really quick follow-up. What would you say the percentage Michael of the products or the revenue that is actually sourced from manufacturing footprints inside of China today versus outside. And thank you very much for indulging my question guys, I appreciate it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matt Ramsay", "section_number": 8, "uuid": "989efd78-97c1-452b-b301-a82dabf4cf2f", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen"}

section.text: It is very convoluted and it is very convoluted and packaging's and also the process wafer manufacturers, and it's very convoluted, we don't have a clear figures now. But going back to the Bernie's question and of Bernie's answers, our technologies, we're using 40 nanometer above and the current sanction is a 14[Phonetic] nanometer below. We are far -- as Bernie mentioned in the script, we are far from that sanctions in the way using the trading edge. We are really using the trading edge of a fab equipment.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Hsing", "section_number": 9, "uuid": "c3231f2c-e0cb-4e68-8da0-8817c44e5460", "speaker_title": "CEO and Founder at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: And if I can just follow-up on one quick point as we made in our script here, is that as the supply demand imbalance has normalized, that frees us up from just being in pure production mode to actually be able to invest time in business relationships, to be able to expand and diversify our capacity, which we talked about about three quarters ago, where we're going to go from $2 billion of capacity currently to $4 billion within the next two years, two to three years.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bernie Blegen", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "1528515c-238d-48de-a752-57578c9f3b42", "speaker_title": "VP and CFO at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: These are mostly, we planned these outside of China.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Hsing", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "e4ab7111-57a3-4470-af58-bcff49571643", "speaker_title": "CEO and Founder at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Yeah.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bernie Blegen", "section_number": 12, "uuid": "cbf382ee-fcce-4685-a8bb-10152dd5aa1d", "speaker_title": "VP and CFO at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Thanks. I don't want to pile on the export control questions that Matt has just asked, but I have one other clarification. You're at 40 nanometer and above and so you're not directly affected. But my understanding is that to the extent a facility, a manufacturing facility in China has multiple process nodes, some above 16 nanometer and some below 16 nanometer that that mixed-use facility would be affected. So I'm just wondering you know, for those Chinese manufacturing facilities, the fab-by-fab, are any of the fabs that you're running 40 nanometer and above, do they also produce 16 nanometers and below and might therefore be affected by equipment and/or support restrictions.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Quinn Bolton", "section_number": 14, "uuid": "d858a2d3-7150-4c44-b8be-4f2a00cd654d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Needham"}

section.text: No. These are fab usually, they don't -- advanced fabs, okay, these are 14 nanometer below, and I did not share where these outdated fabs like 40-nanometer above, okay. We're primarily using 65 nanometer. So these are totally different fabs.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Hsing", "section_number": 15, "uuid": "d4e38771-ba5e-47fb-b53d-590ebf18fb56", "speaker_title": "CEO and Founder at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Thanks Michael. That's right, but I just wanted to clarify because I know that yeah, as Matt said, there have been lots of questions on this topic. Maybe one for Bernie. I know you're not guiding beyond the December quarter. But obviously the environment is pretty tough right now, especially on orders. And so I guess as you look out beyond December, can you give us any thoughts as to whether you would see less than normal seasonality in March as some of this weakness continues into next year? And I guess the offset would be, Monolithic Power has some pretty, I think meaningful market share gains, both on the server CPU side, as well as the data center GPU side. When would you think that those share gains start to kick in and might get you back to normal seasonal if not better than seasonal patterns?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Quinn Bolton", "section_number": 16, "uuid": "2e30ce88-333a-4169-8c49-dbd8aef0aa5e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Needham"}

section.text: Sure. So -- and again Quinn, thank you for focusing on more longer-term and strategic issues here. I think it's very easy to get caught in thinking about next quarter and just the quarter after that. And everything, all the indicators that we're receiving as far as the share gains occurring in the data center are on track. Nothing has been changed there at all. And then as far as how we look at the next few quarters. Again, when we apply cautiousness to Q4, I think we could expect that anything -- that any growth opportunities are more likely to be weighted in the second half of 2023.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bernie Blegen", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "acee82df-e48c-4946-992a-3a76ba1a94db", "speaker_title": "VP and CFO at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Yes, that's our guess and that's our experience. And I might as well add. You mentioned the CPUs and the CPU power, data centers and MPS is a lot more than that. And you look at Bernie's, read our script and you have automotive and the data -- the enterprise data centers and other ones in communication -- the other ones, the communications, these are still, all of them are grown, except the consumer related notebooks, gaming, those type of things, and as everybody is aware of, they are softening. They swing from shortage to oversupplies and then you know kind of almost overnight. These kind of things we cannot predict. I mean you guys probably predict it better than we know. We just have to react fast, and the overall MPS business, all these are greenfield products will start to ramp in the last few years and will continue to ramp.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Hsing", "section_number": 18, "uuid": "add74f6a-6dc3-4406-9e12-53b40925b3c4", "speaker_title": "CEO and Founder at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Sorry Michael, I didn't want to shortchange it by only focusing on the data center opportunity. So, thanks for that color.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Quinn Bolton", "section_number": 19, "uuid": "76886336-bb19-4eda-9d8c-516db09e98c3", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Needham"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bernie Blegen", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "5f369dd1-92df-48c7-b932-e2d7ed23b78e", "speaker_title": "VP and CFO at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Hey. Thank you so much for taking questions. I have one near-term one and then a longer-term one. From a near-term perspective, I'm hoping you can talk about pricing trends and also how your backlog might be changing in terms of the duration of what you have on the books today versus where we've been recently? And then again, I have a sort of longer-term follow-up question, please.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Stein", "section_number": 22, "uuid": "5d7f4a4c-c579-4366-bcef-f4010528055b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Truist Securities"}

section.text: For shorter terms and I can name this. Here what we see is for the long cycle, longer cycle business is continued. And because there is no questions related to price, okay? Because all the products, they will last four, five years or even longer, okay, and these products are in the ramping cycles. In the shortest -- in the shorter cycle, consumer related, as I said it earlier, I have got notebooks and gamings or the other personal electronics, and these ones okay, they are oversupplied. There's no question -- we don't have any questions about the pricing. And that probably will come in, like in later, another quarter later, what will be a new project design, that's where we -- that's pricing -- a question, pricing questions will start to emerge.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Hsing", "section_number": 23, "uuid": "589fc150-61d5-417f-b4b5-af0cea4e27dd", "speaker_title": "CEO and Founder at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: And well, you also mentioned backlog, the sort of condition in the backlog overall. And relative to historical norms, we still remain very -- you know we're much higher than we have been historically, and -- but this has given us an opportunity to address with our customers. In fact, we've been engaged in these conversations for several quarters now, on what they expect real demand to be. So I think that as far as our book of business is looking ahead, it remains very healthy.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bernie Blegen", "section_number": 24, "uuid": "3bb9fb12-00e0-4a8d-9ae0-d80718317d6f", "speaker_title": "VP and CFO at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: And then the longer-term question, I tend to ask each quarter about some of the you know more differentiated products and services MPS has, modules in particular. I wonder about the traction of those products and whether you're seeing the uptake of that either expand or falter given the current environment? And then same thing with e-commerce, like you have seen more or less of that given the changing demand environment. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Stein", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "5757eb1c-d8a3-41c4-8b13-6bd250a7ef11", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Truist Securities"}

section.text: Yes, all the products, the modules and the e-commerce business and we don't see any changes and they are just continuing and that's where MPS future business would be and we're even more diversified than MPS' current business.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Hsing", "section_number": 26, "uuid": "0c43f6c2-ac9e-46bd-885e-3c8858c0c6b2", "speaker_title": "CEO and Founder at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: And I think it's interesting as far as market acceptance for the modules. It really is not concentrated in any one -- any market. It's actually pretty evenly distributed against all of our markets. So that to me is a real clear indicator that it fits in well with our diversification strategy.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bernie Blegen", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "9b54e787-620d-4fce-89c9-912d89b6b1b7", "speaker_title": "VP and CFO at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Yes, frankly if you ask me where this module goes, we don't have ideas and that is the beauty of it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Hsing", "section_number": 28, "uuid": "39d9b347-6f9b-45ae-9c58-f9ebab53d3e4", "speaker_title": "CEO and Founder at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Stein", "section_number": 29, "uuid": "c13e5b2c-9b93-4ae4-90f0-1bbe666020e7", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Truist Securities"}

section.text: Yes, good evening. Can you hear me okay?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeremy Kwan", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "270b95a5-d225-4ceb-a91a-8d0afc6204d1", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Stifel"}

section.text: Yes.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bernie Blegen", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "c227b726-47d8-4298-9f64-77f3afac2c3f", "speaker_title": "VP and CFO at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Great. Just a couple of questions. First, just looking at the lighting business, it looks like it had a nice increase sequentially this quarter. Is there anything that you can call out there? I just want to understand some of the dynamics in that business.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeremy Kwan", "section_number": 33, "uuid": "5c5cb47a-6aa5-4634-a0f9-70fb98c48ad3", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Stifel"}

section.text: Automotive.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bernie Blegen", "section_number": 34, "uuid": "66935d46-4032-4a57-b68f-28d0e01a9bd0", "speaker_title": "VP and CFO at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: I'm sorry, the lighting -- oh, It is automotive. Okay. That's what's been driving it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeremy Kwan", "section_number": 35, "uuid": "77cf0880-032d-4bf0-9faf-0888a79b1476", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Stifel"}

section.text: Yes. As we said in the prepared comments, that there were new platforms that were launched, most of them are tied to the 2023 model year and there were probably three areas, lighting being one of them that really contributed to the uplift in the automotive in Q3.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bernie Blegen", "section_number": 36, "uuid": "b465bdd2-e08a-400b-aad0-544db4c356aa", "speaker_title": "VP and CFO at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: So this is something that we can look at as a new baseline and the sort of like a steady ramp from here or should we expect kind of more step functions with each new model here?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeremy Kwan", "section_number": 37, "uuid": "3bf6c1a3-40fe-4542-96b1-4b494977bc06", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Stifel"}

section.text: Well, the lighting is -- in automotive lighting have a variety. You have a downlight, you have indicators, all kind of indicators, you have the signals, then you have the headlight, okay. So this is the last couple of quarters you see stepping up and that's kind of, that's part of the Greenfield product and automotive start to ramp. The content in the cars, we're growing the content. For the number of cars we have okay, and just at the beginning, we still have a small, very small market here, so it will continue to grow.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Hsing", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "c458ef1a-4909-4f70-9c5a-ccafcfe23474", "speaker_title": "CEO and Founder at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Got it. Great. And just turning to the long term purchasing agreement that you talked about Bernie, can you give us a little bit more details on this, maybe the magnitude or the size of this deal and you know how different is this from things, the way you may have done business in the past. Just any more detail and help us you know to understand your strategic thinking behind this, that would be very helpful.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeremy Kwan", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "d4c7354e-6d4d-434e-8ab0-b14754820cc0", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Stifel"}

section.text: Sure. So when you think about the period of the supply-demand imbalance we came out of, we had actually a superior competitive position because we had invested in our supply chain earlier than our competition, and that allowed us to have part availability when they didn't and that allowed for incremental market share gains. So as we continue to expand capacity, we're looking for new opportunities and with existing as well as with new fabs, and so in this instance we wanted to secure a purchasing agreement that in order -- that gave us dedicated capacity regardless of what the economic environment was.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bernie Blegen", "section_number": 40, "uuid": "a6c01428-1b54-4a92-9097-3a17de0ec122", "speaker_title": "VP and CFO at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Got it, thank you. And then just one last question, just touching again on the modules. Can you give us any insight into the other differences in terms of the manufacturing supply chain that needs to be managed here? And you know in terms of whether it's sourcing or whether it's the geographic footprint. Are there things that you can call there as well?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeremy Kwan", "section_number": 41, "uuid": "6e5f2924-939b-44b1-b759-06e6aa582369", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Stifel"}

section.text: Most of it -- let me answer it that way. Most of our modules assembly is outside of China.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Hsing", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "f605eb8b-c368-4f9f-b6f6-f529844a9f96", "speaker_title": "CEO and Founder at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Great. Thank you very much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeremy Kwan", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "ceeb1649-3f5a-45b4-b7d6-929d67aab654", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Stifel"}

section.text: Rick, can you hear us?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bernie Blegen", "section_number": 45, "uuid": "ffa11a37-f850-4142-81b6-94ec6a0d7212", "speaker_title": "VP and CFO at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Yes, sorry I was muted. Can you hear me now, Bernie?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Rick Schafer", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "fc5adef4-8d0e-4b27-b950-7a61a96f407d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Oppenheimer"}

section.text: Yes.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bernie Blegen", "section_number": 47, "uuid": "20f3568a-4b49-4740-b0f7-fdf609a47b58", "speaker_title": "VP and CFO at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Great. Well hey guys. Thanks for letting me ask you a question. Maybe my first one just on supply. You know TSM, obviously your newest foundry partner, I was just curious if you could kind of level set us on where you guys are at in terms of the qualification process, you know eventual capacity ramp, sort of maybe even get a sense of how much capacity they are going to have for you ultimately and how much of that might be eight versus 12-inch? Just trying to get a better handle on them as a partner.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Rick Schafer", "section_number": 48, "uuid": "948d72e1-8535-4d5b-a3cf-08ac2497e53e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Oppenheimer"}

section.text: Yes, most of what we use is 12-inch and also the advanced process modes, of course that thing is in the TSMC. We do use the advanced nodes of gaming and these are for microcontrollers, that type of a product that we do use them and these are not winning in China at all. And a lot of these are product at the very beginning of a ramp and so now we have all the capacities for these new products. Mostly these are for automotive and communications and so now it gives us a lot more room to grow.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Hsing", "section_number": 49, "uuid": "abc85c0f-4f46-49ce-a6f5-7fecf9f50dd9", "speaker_title": "CEO and Founder at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: So Michael, just to kind of get a sense. I mean, is this -- could TSM be sort of a 10% contributor to capacity in say a year's time or is that too aggressive to kind of think of how quickly they could ramp?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Rick Schafer", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "38dd8145-49a7-43a8-a022-2faeed43f2e6", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Oppenheimer"}

section.text: On the lower side as we see now.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Hsing", "section_number": 51, "uuid": "4bcf5633-fe71-4c47-9906-6df412978f57", "speaker_title": "CEO and Founder at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Thanks a lot and then a follow-up, I'm just curious to get an update on silicon carbide progress, particularly traction inverters. I mean how many customers you're engaged with now and when we might expect to see initial revenues? And I know you've talked about it in the past Michael, but just kind of remind us what that dollar content for MPS looks like ex-EV? And I'm assuming it would be sort of subsystem, but would anything be discrete or would that all be sort of module/subsystem?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Rick Schafer", "section_number": 52, "uuid": "58b808ae-3a1e-47ce-aa79-a2de1f329072", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Oppenheimer"}

section.text: Yes. Thank you very much to ask that question. Yeah, that kind of things, the silicon carbides and the high-power modules okay, that work gets me excited. We do have our first product going through the qualification now; it's working. MPS does not intend to sell as a power device -- as a power device only and like a power set only. We will sell within using our combined with our silicon technology produce these small modules. And we do have many customers engaged in automotive, automotive sections and also the large energy storage and as well as BMS, the car charging stations and those kind of things, we don't have any revenue yet, okay, but it will be in the next few years.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Hsing", "section_number": 53, "uuid": "9d0b1982-5cfb-4709-9829-0d7c97b1d6c4", "speaker_title": "CEO and Founder at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: And Michael, just a reminder just sort of what it does to content for you guys or potential content in a car or a vehicle?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Rick Schafer", "section_number": 54, "uuid": "6c627e59-53da-4584-b4f1-4e950985a8da", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Oppenheimer"}

section.text: I think these content will be enormous, okay? I don't even have a -- that would be in the billion, and I don't have a -- a couple of billion dollars of opportunity is a smaller. It's a very conservative estimate. Just thinking about it, all the power trains okay, driver trains, all the charging stations, MPS is not going to make and sell a chip only, we are selling the entire systems.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Hsing", "section_number": 55, "uuid": "91b4155b-f7a2-4a26-93af-cae2810e79c3", "speaker_title": "CEO and Founder at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Great. Thanks a lot for all the color.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Rick Schafer", "section_number": 56, "uuid": "c2f6d2b2-fe17-4c97-b6b0-4c4ff53b9ad8", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Oppenheimer"}

section.text: Hey everyone. Thanks for taking my questions. Bernie, maybe one for you just on a housekeeping question around gross margins. Can you elaborate a little bit on the down sequential? The only reason I'm asking is given the end market weakness and notebooks in consumer I would have thought is lower gross margin mix. So anything you can do to help on that and how to think of it like from here?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Alex Vecchi", "section_number": 58, "uuid": "e17f8051-e850-4876-83e8-bcc342cad844", "speaker_title": "Analyst at William Blair"}

section.text: Sure, Alex. So there's a lot of ingredients that play into the gross margin outlook and certainly the direct margin by end market is a significant part of it. Another is the amount of I don't like to call it necessarily unused capacity. The fixed cost that isn't necessarily absorbed by the same volume. So it's really the fixed cost issue as opposed to the sales mix that's putting a little bit of downward pressure on the gross margin.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Hsing", "section_number": 59, "uuid": "0789812b-11f7-47ba-8643-40faf113e529", "speaker_title": "CEO and Founder at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Okay. And then similarly to that extent, just expand on Rick's questions regarding the new fab partner or TSMC. Do you view that relationship eventually being gross margin accretive or dilutive versus your Chinese partners?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Alex Vecchi", "section_number": 60, "uuid": "69091b76-35bb-4911-a0ca-dfd4aafbb52d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at William Blair"}

section.text: Well, these are the events note and we're moving that towards that -- in the territories and therefore these are more microcontrollers, and more highly digital content products and it's a different product. We -- there is no gross margin issues. So in that case we don't go down compete with the price. All the products that we add is more. These are values more in the software side.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Hsing", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "ca8370fb-cd07-4b82-88ef-2c1ca581cce0", "speaker_title": "CEO and Founder at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: And I think that when you look at TSMC, these are new and advanced products that we're developing with them, whereas we're at the same time doing an expansion and diversification away from China and that would include other fabs, both in South Korea as well as in Taiwan.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bernie Blegen", "section_number": 62, "uuid": "a2523e02-85bd-4059-90c4-4a4cd7ff6753", "speaker_title": "VP and CFO at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Okay, that is really helpful. With that, I will go back into queue. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Alex Vecchi", "section_number": 63, "uuid": "2f11597c-6e42-441b-8cdb-f98a73b079a4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at William Blair"}

section.text: Hi guys. Thanks very much. We saw capex -- maybe a little longer-term question for you. We saw capex dip a little in the third quarter. Maybe could you give us an update on your longer-term capacity planning, not just with TSMC, but more broadly? Does the near-term demand weakness impact those longer-term plans? And then when we're looking at getting to $4 billion in revenue, what's the path to that ramp and the cadence of the investment needed to get there?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Melissa Fairbanks", "section_number": 65, "uuid": "b0624312-4a4c-45e8-a63e-191ef1ede905", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Raymond James"}

section.text: Well, it's a -- we always -- if you look at our past. If you look at how we expand our capacity, what is our investment, and if you look at the past eight, nine, 12 years, it's the same pattern as the next four, five years. And we're not going to over invest. We're not going to less invest it, okay. So the trend, if you look at it. If you're plotting our opex and also the growth rate, and it should remain pretty constant in the past four years and in the past eight years, in 12 years, in also the last two or three years the growth pattern is really different from previous four years, and whatever the growth rate we have in the next four years, you can use the plotting -- you can use the same kind of percentage range.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Hsing", "section_number": 66, "uuid": "682edcf3-e377-4029-aab2-1c006640c4e6", "speaker_title": "CEO and Founder at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: And Melissa, keep in mind that when we do the fab expansion, the capital expenditures are borne by our partners not directly by us. So when you look at our run rate that Michael is referring to, that's more heavily concentrated in test equipment, which can fluctuate from anywhere between $8 million per quarter to $14 million per quarter. It just so happens that we made a lot of those investments earlier in the year, and that's why we're lower. The other thing that we invest in is that we do buy or we develop our own facilities and those can be layered on and currently there are no investments of any material nature.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bernie Blegen", "section_number": 67, "uuid": "bd7fc549-f6bd-4d77-a9c6-18268d169bb9", "speaker_title": "VP and CFO at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Yes, let me clarify this a little more, rather than give you a model. You know MPS, we don't own the fab, we don't own fab equipment, and the cost of associating with capacity expansion, one is we have to qualify the process, and the large portion of it is to qualify our products. We have 4,000, well over 4,000 products, and each product to go through a qualification, that takes about eight to nine months. That cost, that's very costly and so that's -- if we don't -- if we slow down and the demand slows down, we don't have to qualify as fast okay, and so the cost will be spread out.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Hsing", "section_number": 68, "uuid": "64741dd3-d4d3-4a37-ad21-1a79319e0522", "speaker_title": "CEO and Founder at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: And those costs are borne in our R&D expenditure line.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bernie Blegen", "section_number": 69, "uuid": "f590cb3c-860a-4b6d-81d9-51eef20a2e41", "speaker_title": "VP and CFO at Monolithic Power Systems"}

section.text: Okay great, that is very clear. Thanks very much guys.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Melissa Fairbanks", "section_number": 70, "uuid": "587eac47-5fa7-4bb7-a358-63301c47dfb3", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Raymond James"}

section.text: Thanks Jen. I'd like to thank you all for joining us for this conference call and look forward to talking to you again during the fourth quarter conference call, which is likely to be held in early February. Thank you and have a nice day.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bernie Blegen", "section_number": 72, "uuid": "9aa03c92-c10f-4929-b7fb-e79e79342002", "speaker_title": "VP and CFO at Monolithic Power Systems"}

title: Q&A for MPWR (Monolithic Power Systems) on 10/27/22 4:30 PM ET
